articles.headline: After Raising $90 Million in 2020, Black Lives Matter Has $42 Million in Assets
articles.snippet: The organization offered the first official accounting of its finances recently, disclosing a filing to the I.R.S.
articles.abstract: The organization offered the first official accounting of its finances recently, disclosing a filing to the I.R.S.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the tragic, whirlwind year of 2020, with racial-justice protests prompted by the killing of Black men and women by police officers, the Black Lives Matter Global Network Foundation raised $90 million, much of it small donations from rank-and-file supporters. A recent tax filing from the group shows that by the middle of last year, more than half of that money had been granted to smaller organizations or spent on consultants and real estate, leaving the foundation with $42 million in assets.

articles.headline: Justice Dept. Is Said to Request Transcripts From Jan. 6 Committee
articles.snippet: The committee has interviewed more than 1,000 people so far, and the transcripts could be used as evidence in potential criminal cases or to pursue new leads.
articles.abstract: The committee has interviewed more than 1,000 people so far, and the transcripts could be used as evidence in potential criminal cases or to pursue new leads.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department has asked the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack for transcripts of interviews it is conducting behind closed doors, including some with associates of former President Donald J. Trump, according to people with knowledge of the situation.
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush and Luke Broadwater

articles.headline: Ukrainian Holdouts in Mariupol Surrender to an Uncertain Fate
articles.snippet: The government’s order for hundreds of remaining fighters to stand down offers Russia a propaganda victory, but prospects for a prisoner swap seem unclear at best.
articles.abstract: The government’s order for hundreds of remaining fighters to stand down offers Russia a propaganda victory, but prospects for a prisoner swap seem unclear at best.
articles.lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Hundreds of die-hard Ukrainian soldiers who had made a last stand against Russian forces from a Mariupol steel mill faced an uncertain future Tuesday under Kremlin custody after Ukraine’s military ordered them to surrender.
articles.byline: By Valerie Hopkins, Marc Santora, Ivan Nechepurenko and Rick Gladstone

articles.headline: U.S. Gun Production Triples Since 2000, Fueled by Handgun Purchases
articles.snippet: The A.T.F. released a trove of gun manufacturing data on Tuesday, the first comprehensive survey of firearms commerce data in decades.
articles.abstract: The A.T.F. released a trove of gun manufacturing data on Tuesday, the first comprehensive survey of firearms commerce data in decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States is in the middle of a great gun-buying boom that shows no sign of letting up as the annual number of firearms manufactured has nearly tripled since 2000 and spiked sharply in the past three years, according to the first comprehensive federal tally of gun commerce in two decades.

articles.headline: Omens of Decline for Russia’s Once World-Leading Energy Industry
articles.snippet: Sanctions have grounded Russia’s ambitious plans to build its liquefied natural gas capacity. Analysts say it’s a sign of problems ahead.
articles.abstract: Sanctions have grounded Russia’s ambitious plans to build its liquefied natural gas capacity. Analysts say it’s a sign of problems ahead.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was to be a hugely ambitious project on the frigid Gulf of Ob, in Russia’s Far North, a steppingstone in Moscow’s rising ambitions to be a power in liquefied natural gas much as it is in oil and gas delivered by pipeline.

articles.headline: Biden Health Officials Warn of Substantial Increase in Virus Cases
articles.snippet: The director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention urged local leaders and individuals to at least consider returning to wearing masks in indoor public settings.
articles.abstract: The director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention urged local leaders and individuals to at least consider returning to wearing masks in indoor public settings.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal health officials warned on Wednesday that a third of Americans live in areas where the threat of Covid-19 is now so high that they should consider wearing a mask in indoor public settings. They cited new data showing a substantial jump in both the spread of the coronavirus and hospitalizations over the past week.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere, Michael D. Shear and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: China’s Internet Censors Try a New Trick: Revealing Users’ Locations
articles.snippet: The rapidly expanding practice, which authorities say helps combat disinformation from abroad, has fueled a whole new type of online battle.
articles.abstract: The rapidly expanding practice, which authorities say helps combat disinformation from abroad, has fueled a whole new type of online battle.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years China’s censors have relied on a trusted tool kit to control the country’s internet. They have deleted posts, suspended accounts, blocked keywords, and arrested the most outspoken.

articles.headline: How a Trash-Talking Crypto Founder Caused a $40 Billion Crash
articles.snippet: Do Kwon, a South Korean entrepreneur, hyped the Luna and TerraUSD cryptocurrencies. Their failures have devastated some traders, though not the investment firms that cashed out early.
articles.abstract: Do Kwon, a South Korean entrepreneur, hyped the Luna and TerraUSD cryptocurrencies. Their failures have devastated some traders, though not the investment firms that cashed out early.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By David Yaffe-Bellany and Erin Griffith

articles.headline: Economic Headwinds Mount as Leaders Weigh Costs of Confronting Russia
articles.snippet: Top economic officials are gathering this week to discuss how to keep pressure on Vladimir V. Putin without sinking their economies.
articles.abstract: Top economic officials are gathering this week to discuss how to keep pressure on Vladimir V. Putin without sinking their economies.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The world economy is heading into a potentially grim period as rising costs, shortages of food and other commodities and Russia’s continuing invasion of Ukraine threaten to slow economic growth and bring about a painful global slump.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport and Patricia Cohen
